label: Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot
title: Pepper - bell Bacterial spot
description: bell Bacterial spot is a plant disease affecting pepper plants. This condition can significantly impact plant health and crop yields.
symptoms:
• Visible lesions or spots on leaves
• Discoloration of plant tissues
• Potential leaf yellowing or browning
• Reduced plant vigor
causes:
• Pathogenic organisms (fungi, bacteria, or viruses)
• Environmental stress conditions
• Poor air circulation
• Excessive moisture
treatment:
• Remove affected plant parts immediately
• Apply appropriate fungicides or bactericides
• Improve air circulation
• Adjust watering practices
prevention:
• Use certified disease-free seeds
• Practice crop rotation (3-4 years)
• Ensure proper plant spacing
• Avoid overhead watering
prognosis: Good with early detection and proper treatment. Yield losses can be minimized with integrated management.
economic_impact: Can cause significant yield reduction if left untreated. Early intervention reduces economic losses.
reference: Plant Pathology Guidelines, Agricultural Extension Services

label: Pepper__bell___healthy
title: Pepper - Healthy
description: No visible disease symptoms. The pepper plant appears healthy with normal leaf color and structure.
symptoms:
• Deep green, uniform leaf color
• Strong, upright plant structure
• Normal leaf size and shape
• No signs of wilting or yellowing
causes:
• Optimal growing conditions
• Proper nutrition and watering
• Good air circulation
• Absence of pathogenic organisms
treatment:
• Continue regular monitoring
• Maintain consistent watering
• Apply balanced fertilizer as needed
• Ensure proper plant support
prevention:
• Use certified, disease-free seeds
• Practice crop rotation
• Maintain optimal soil conditions
• Monitor weather conditions
prognosis: Excellent. Healthy plants can achieve maximum yield potential with continued proper management.
economic_impact: Healthy plants maximize economic returns with premium quality produce and minimal input costs.
reference: Standard Agricultural Best Practices, University Extension Guidelines

label: Tomato___Late_blight
title: Tomato - Late Blight
description: Late blight is a devastating fungal disease affecting tomato plants. This condition can significantly impact plant health and crop yields.
symptoms:
• Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems
• White fungal growth on leaf undersides
• Brown to black lesions that spread rapidly
• Fruit rot with dark, firm lesions
• Plant collapse in severe cases
causes:
• Phytophthora infestans fungus
• High humidity (>90%) conditions
• Cool temperatures (60-70°F)
• Poor air circulation
• Overhead watering or rain
treatment:
• Remove and destroy affected plant parts immediately
• Apply copper-based fungicides preventively
• Use systemic fungicides (chlorothalonil, mancozeb)
• Improve air circulation around plants
• Avoid overhead watering
prevention:
• Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants
• Practice crop rotation (avoid tomatoes/potatoes for 3-4 years)
• Ensure proper plant spacing for air circulation
• Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering
• Apply preventive fungicide sprays in high-risk conditions
prognosis: Poor to fair. Can cause complete crop loss if untreated. Early detection and aggressive treatment essential.
economic_impact: Can cause 50-100% yield loss. Major economic threat to tomato production worldwide. Estimated billions in annual losses globally.
reference: University Extension Services, Plant Pathology Textbooks, USDA Guidelines
